figures.title: Clinical Symptoms and Serology at Diagnosis
figures.description: This figure consists of two pie charts showing clinical data at the time of diagnosis. The larger pie chart displays the distribution of clinical symptoms, with ear symptoms being most common (83 cases, 31%), followed by sinus (63 cases, 23%) and nose symptoms (63 cases, 23%). The smaller pie chart shows serology results, with PR3 being predominant (142 cases) compared to MPO (29 cases), indicating the serological profile of the patient cohort.
figures.caption: Clinical symptoms at the time of diagnosis

figures.title: Treatment Drug Distribution by Phase
figures.description: This is a dual bar chart comparing treatment drug frequencies and percentages between induction (Panel A) and maintenance (Panel B) phases. Panel A shows CYC as the most frequently used induction treatment (123 patients, 55.9%), followed by PDN pulse (111 patients, 50.5%) and MTX (51 patients, 23.2%). Panel B demonstrates MTX as the dominant maintenance therapy (75 patients, 34.1%), followed by AZA (43 patients, 19.5%) and Rituximab (20 patients, 9.1%). The data reveals distinct treatment patterns between induction and maintenance phases, with different drugs preferred for each therapeutic stage.
figures.caption: Fig. 3 A) Patients under induction treatment. B) Patients under maintenance treatment

figures.title: Survival Analysis by GI Involvement Status
figures.description: This figure presents Kaplan-Meier survival curves comparing two groups based on gastrointestinal (GI) involvement status. The left panel shows overall survival and the right panel shows relapse-free survival over follow-up periods of up to 100 months and 60 months respectively. Both curves demonstrate significantly worse outcomes for the GI involvement positive group (red line) compared to the negative group (blue line), with steeper declines in both overall survival and relapse-free survival rates. The survival curves show clear separation between groups, indicating GI involvement is associated with poorer prognosis.
figures.caption: Overall survival (left) and Relapse free survival (right) analysis

figures.title: Vasculitis Classification Algorithm Decision Tree
figures.description: This is a clinical decision flowchart that shows a systematic approach to classifying different types of vasculitis in patients with a clinical diagnosis. The algorithm starts with patients diagnosed with vasculitis and uses sequential criteria including ACR (American College of Rheumatology) guidelines, biopsy results, and ANCA testing to differentiate between EGPA (Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis), GPA (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis), MPA (Microscopic Polyangiitis), and PAN (Polyarteritis Nodosa). Each decision point leads to either a specific vasculitis classification or continues to the next diagnostic criterion, with cases that don't meet any criteria being labeled as 'Unclassified'.
figures.caption: Page 3 of 10 Siri et al. BMC Rheumatology           (2025) 9:129

figures.title: Medical Abbreviations and Acknowledgements List
figures.description: This is a reference list or glossary containing medical and research abbreviations with their full definitions. The list includes disease classifications (EGPA, PAN), medical tests and enzymes (AST, ALT, MPO), body systems and organs (ENT, lung, kidney), treatments (cyclophosphamide, rituximab), and statistical terms (SPSS, ANCOVA). The figure also includes acknowledgements and author contributions sections, indicating this is likely from the end matter of a medical research paper focused on vasculitis or related autoimmune conditions.
figures.caption: Acknowledgements Authors would like to appreciate the support and constructive comments of  the methodologist(s) research development office, Imamkhomeini Hospital  complex, Tehran, Iran.
